runs.text: Insert Graphic Here and Remove Box

The Department of Veterans Affairs (VA) lacks a structured, scalable system to map Veterans Affairs Schedule for Rating Disabilities (VASRD) codes to standardized medical codes. This gap makes it difficult for adjudicators to efficiently evaluate claims, leading to processing delays and inconsistent evaluations. Amida’s MCP team currently performs this mapping manually, which is time-consuming and not scalable.
Amida developed a custom Extraction-Compaction-Expansion-Unified Medical Language System (UMLS) API (ECEU) workflow​ to map relevant medical codes to the VASRD. The process is as follows:
Extract medical concepts (e.g., diagnoses, medications, procedures, and labs) from
/VASRD criteria and map them to standardized medical terminologies
Use LLM-driven keyword expansion and the UMLS API to identify relevant medical codes
Apply VASRD criteria-based filters to the medical codes to ensure result accuracy and clinical relevance
​The VACM automation initiative enables the MCP team to accelerate the mapping process, expediting over 114,000 claims and reducing claim resolution time for more than 4.4 million veterans.

This workflow automates the Extraction, Compaction, and Expansion of VASRD keywords, followed by a UMLS API query (ECEU). In the initial phase, the Python script extracts raw terminology from the Code of Federal Regulations (CFR). In the second phase, the process removes non-essential words (e.g., prepositions, conjunctions) and use Llama 3.2 to generate and expand related medical terms. The following validation step filters out irrelevant keywords to ensure that only valid terms advance to the mapping stage. The final phase initiates UMLS API integration, maps clinical codes to the generated keyword set, and eliminates unrelated clinical codes to maximize result accuracy.
ECEU (Extraction, Compaction, Expansion, and UMLS API) workflow. Medical concepts are extracted

runs.text: function determines whether a given code description is directly or indirectly related to a specified VASRD disease (e.g., Sarcoidosis). The function returns “yes” if related, otherwise “no,” enforcing a strict binary output.

runs.text: ICD-10 code identification process. Additional filtering reduced ECEU results from 2,517 to 1,703 codes
improving precision while retaining alignment with 141 of the 147 source codes identified in the SME’s manual process. This refinement increases approach accuracy without sacrificing coverage.

This table compares ECEU results across multiple medical conditions. Each row lists a condition and its associated VASRD code, detailing the clinical code mapping. The "Source Codes" column displays the initial validated codes, while the "ECEU Results“ column captures the unfiltered mapping output. The "Filtered ECEU Results" column highlights the significant reduction in false positives after LLM processing, ranging from 43% (Sarcoidosis) to 77% (Irritable Bowel Syndrome). The "Common Codes" column confirms retention of over 90% of source codes for most conditions, while “Missing Codes” tracks minimal losses. This comparative analysis demonstrates how our approach substantially improves precision in VASRD-to-medical code and preserves comprehensive coverage across diverse medical conditions.

runs.text: – This code snippet demonstrates a preprocessing function called
. The function tokenizes the input text into words, converts them to lowercase for uniformity, and removes common

to focus on meaningful terms. It lemmatizes the tokens, reducing them to their base or root form, and removes punctuation and special characters to eliminate unnecessary noise. Additionally, duplicate words are removed while preserving the order of occurrence. Finally, the cleaned tokens are joined back into a single string. This cleaning process is crucial because the
descriptions contain a lot of noise and repeated words, making them unsuitable for embedding and similarity measurement.

is a powerful general-purpose model, while

the results to determine the most effective one for the project.

elements.filename: C:\Users\Shreya B\Documents\GitHub\slide-review-agent\data\logs\assets\amida vacm project presentation -may 2 2025 -final for mukundan\40_03.png

runs.text: Cosine similarity analysis was implemented to quantify the textual relationship between Sarcoidosis (Condition) and ICD-10 code descriptions. The computed similarity scores exhibited a range from
in the API output results, while Hannah's codes demonstrated scores from

. Although cosine similarity excels at measuring textual alignment between vector representations, the substantial overlap in score distributions suggests its limitations in distinctly separating the approved codes from the broader API output set. This overlap presents a significant challenge in reliably identifying and ranking the 147 validated codes within the top 500 results.

elements.filename: C:\Users\Shreya B\Documents\GitHub\slide-review-agent\data\logs\assets\amida vacm project presentation -may 2 2025 -final for mukundan\41_03.png

runs.text: – Euclidean distance is used to measure the similarity between two points. In this analysis, vector embeddings were generated for the Sarcoidosis ECFR description and approximately 75,000 ICD-10 code descriptions using the text-embedding-3-large. Without applying normalization or dimensionality reduction, the L2 norm is calculated. ICD-10 Codes were sorted based on their L2 norm scores, with lower scores indicating higher similarity. The top 200 codes with the lowest L2 norm scores were compared to a curated list of 147 Sarcoidosis-related ICD-10 codes. Among the top 200 codes, 20 matched the curated list, and in the top 500, 29 codes matched. While the match is limited, refining the ECFR description by incorporating all known symptoms of Sarcoidosis using a LLM has the potential to improve the relevance and accuracy of the results.

elements.filename: C:\Users\Shreya B\Documents\GitHub\slide-review-agent\data\logs\assets\amida vacm project presentation -may 2 2025 -final for mukundan\42_03.png
C:\Users\Shreya B\Documents\GitHub\slide-review-agent\data\logs\assets\amida vacm project presentation -may 2 2025 -final for mukundan\42_04.png

runs.text: In our analysis, Euclidean distance serves as a key metric to evaluate the semantic relationship between Sarcoidosis (Condition) and ICD-10 code descriptions across two distinct datasets: API output results and Hannah's codes. The API output encompasses 2,564 codes, while Hannah's dataset contains 147 thoroughly validated codes. Our Euclidean distance calculations revealed a distribution ranging from

in Hannah's dataset. Notably, the overlapping distance ranges indicate that Euclidean distance, may not provide optimal differentiation for identifying the 147 validated codes within the broader API Output Results.

elements.filename: C:\Users\Shreya B\Documents\GitHub\slide-review-agent\data\logs\assets\amida vacm project presentation -may 2 2025 -final for mukundan\43_03.png

runs.text: - The process begins by using data from two sources: ECFR descriptions as seed points and approximately 75,000 ICD-10 code descriptions as data points. Vector embeddings for both the data sources are generated using the text-embedding-3-large model, converting textual information into numeric vectors. These embeddings are then reduced to two dimensions using Principal Component Analysis (PCA), allowing for normalized visualization. Subsequently, the Voronoi methodology is applied, which partitions the 2D space based on Euclidean distances. Each seed point (ECFR description) becomes the

of a region, and all data points (ICD-10 code descriptions) within a region are closer to that seed point than to any other. This technique effectively clusters and organizes the data points around their respective seed points.

elements.filename: C:\Users\Shreya B\Documents\GitHub\slide-review-agent\data\logs\assets\amida vacm project presentation -may 2 2025 -final for mukundan\44_03.png

runs.text: – The image shows the Voronoi polygon for Sarcoidosis. Voronoi is performed for 6 ECFR health conditions. For detailed analysis, we focused on one seed point, Sarcoidosis. From the Voronoi results, we identified 5,487 ICD-10 codes (data points) associated with Sarcoidosis (seed point). To evaluate these results, we compared them with Hannah's team's result, which contains 147 ICD-10 codes related to Sarcoidosis. Out of Voronoi's identified codes, 47 matched the existing list. While the match is limited, this result reflects some inherent challenges. Each data point is assigned to only one seed point region, which might not fully capture cases where data points could relate to multiple health conditions. Additionally, the dimensionality reduction step (PCA), though essential for visualization, may have contributed to minor distortions in the clustering.

elements.filename: C:\Users\Shreya B\Documents\GitHub\slide-review-agent\data\logs\assets\amida vacm project presentation -may 2 2025 -final for mukundan\45_03.png
C:\Users\Shreya B\Documents\GitHub\slide-review-agent\data\logs\assets\amida vacm project presentation -may 2 2025 -final for mukundan\45_04.png
C:\Users\Shreya B\Documents\GitHub\slide-review-agent\data\logs\assets\amida vacm project presentation -may 2 2025 -final for mukundan\46_02.png

runs.text: The table illustrates how data points are distributed among four seed points: Sarcoidosis, Asthma, Brain Cancer, and Fibromyalgia, based on embeddings of ECFR descriptions. In total, there are approximately 73,500 data points representing vector embeddings of ICD-10 code descriptions. Voronoi partitioning was applied using cosine similarity, which assigns each data point to the seed point with the highest similarity. This method allows for the grouping of data points based on their similarity to the seed points, providing a structured way to categorize ECFR descriptions. By examining these groupings, we gain valuable insights into the relationships and relevance of ICD-10 codes to each seed point, shedding light on how medical conditions are distributed and interconnected based on their descriptions.

elements.filename: C:\Users\Shreya B\Documents\GitHub\slide-review-agent\data\logs\assets\amida vacm project presentation -may 2 2025 -final for mukundan\47_02.png

runs.text: The table shows how data points are distributed among the four seed points: Sarcoidosis, Asthma, Brain Cancer, and Fibromyalgia, which are based on the embeddings of ECFR descriptions. In total, there are approximately 73,500 data points representing vector embeddings of ICD-10 code descriptions. To

the data, Voronoi partitioning was applied using Euclidean distance. This method assigns each data point to the nearest seed point by calculating the Euclidean distance between the data point and the seed points. This approach helps identify patterns and relationships between ECFR descriptions and their closest seed points, offering a structured way to group similar data. By
these groupings, we gain insights into the relevance of each seed point to the ICD-10 codes, uncovering how medical conditions are distributed and interconnected based on their descriptions.

elements.filename: C:\Users\Shreya B\Documents\GitHub\slide-review-agent\data\logs\assets\amida vacm project presentation -may 2 2025 -final for mukundan\48_02.png

runs.text: The figure illustrates the architecture of a Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) system. The process begins by embedding ICD-10 code descriptions into a vector embeddings using text-embedding-3-large embedding model. These embeddings are stored in a vector database to enable efficient semantic search. When a user submits a health condition as a query, it is converted into a vector embedding and passed to a retriever, which searches the vector database to find the most relevant ICD-10 descriptions. The retrieved information is then fed into a large language model (LLM), which combines this contextual input with its pretrained knowledge to generate a comprehensive and query-specific response. This integrated process of retrieval and generation ensures precise, relevant, and highly contextualized outputs for medical code queries.

– This work builds upon the concepts discussed in Slide 26, extending the implementation to refine the RAG pipeline for ICD-10 code retrieval and generation. The RAG pipeline combines vector embeddings and LLM to retrieve ICD-10 codes based on input queries. Vector embeddings are generated for ICD-10 code descriptions and stored in a FAISS index utilizing IndexFlatL2, which relies on L2 norm (Euclidean distance) for similarity searches. During the retrieval process, an embedding is generated for the input query and compared with the stored embeddings to retrieve the top k results. The retrieval process is configured with k=500, the top 500 most relevant ICD-10 codes are retained based on similarity ranking. Analysis shows that only 29 of the ICD-10 codes matched within the top 500 results, leaving 118 ICD-10 codes unretrieved. Since the generation process in RAG relies on the retrieved data, any missing codes in the retrieval stage are inherently excluded from the generation phase. This dependency emphasizes that the quality and completeness of the retrieved data directly impact the accuracy and comprehensiveness of the generated results. Without retrieving all relevant codes, the generated output may fail to capture the full scope of the input query, making the current RAG approach insufficient.

slides.title: Conceptual Framework for Graph-Based ICD-10 Filtering

runs.text: Conceptual Framework for Graph-Based ICD-10 Filtering

elements.filename: C:\Users\Shreya B\Documents\GitHub\slide-review-agent\data\logs\assets\amida vacm project presentation -may 2 2025 -final for mukundan\51_02.png

runs.text: This diagram demonstrates our conceptual framework for graph-based ICD-10 filtering. Here we visualize the (synthetic) connectivity patterns between ICD-10 (dark blue dots) and VASRD codes (light blue dots). The diagram showcases two distinct patterns of code relationships: Looking at the top section, we see examples of indiscriminate ICD-10 codes (marked in the red boxes) that are overconnected to multiple VASRD nodes. These create a complex web of relationships, indicating low selectivity and a high probability of false positives. Such codes are less useful for precise medical classification. In contrast, the middle and lower sections display ICD-10 codes (marked in the green boxes) that show selective connectivity to VASRD nodes. We expect this transform to significantly reduce false positives and improve the accuracy of our classification system.

elements.filename: C:\Users\Shreya B\Documents\GitHub\slide-review-agent\data\logs\assets\amida vacm project presentation -may 2 2025 -final for mukundan\51_13.png

runs.text: Precise match with selective VASRD links: high relevance, low false positives.
Overconnected to multiple VASRD codes: low selectivity, high
This graph visualizes the relationship between VASRD
ICD-10 codes (red dots on the right)

, highlighting their connections. We observe that multiple ICD-10 codes are linked to both unique VASRD codes, which aligns with our theory that these shared ICD codes contribute significantly to false positives. By identifying and removing these overlapping ICD-10 codes, we aim to effectively reduce false positives.

slides.title: Graph Theory: Results of ICD-10 Codes with Maximum of 24 VASRD Connections (97.5%ile)

runs.text: Graph Theory: Results of ICD-10 Codes with Maximum of 24 VASRD Connections (97.5%ile)
Total number of unique ICD-10 Codes (ECE Output for 100 VASRD Codes): 44238 ICD-10 codes​
Total number of unique ICD-10 codes (ECE Output + Graph Theory for 100 VASRD Codes):

Our ECE process generated 44,238 unique ICD-10 codes for 100 VASRD codes. After applying graph theory, we retained the 97.5th percentile of total ICD-10 codes (ECE output), resulting in 43,255 ICD-10 codes. We applied graph theory to these six conditions: Sarcoidosis, Brain Cancer, Asthma, Fibromyalgia, Irritable Bowel Syndrome, and Breast Cancer. For Sarcoidosis, Hannah's original set of 147 codes was narrowed down to 117 codes. Similarly, our ECE output for Sarcoidosis was refined from 2,564 to 2,289 codes after applying the same graph theory filtering, which comprehensively included all 117 of Hannah's codes.

elements.filename: C:\Users\Shreya B\Documents\GitHub\slide-review-agent\data\logs\assets\amida vacm project presentation -may 2 2025 -final for mukundan\54_04.png

slides.title: Graph Theory: Results of ICD-10 Codes with Maximum of 16 VASRD Connections (95%ile)

runs.text: Graph Theory: Results of ICD-10 Codes with Maximum of 16 VASRD Connections (95%ile)

Our ECE process generated 44,238 unique ICD-10 codes for 100 VASRD codes. After applying the graph theory, we retained 95th percentile  of total ICD-10 codes (ECE output) resulting in 42,158 ICD-10 codes. We applied graph theory for these six conditions: Sarcoidosis, Brain Cancer, Asthma, Fibromyalgia, Irritable Bowel Syndrome, Breast Cancer. For Sarcoidosis, Hannah's original set of 147 codes were narrowed down to 72 codes. Similarly, our ECE output for Sarcoidosis was refined from 2,564 to 1,789 codes after applying the same graph theory filtering,
which comprehensively included all 72 of Hannah's codes
. The table shows similar results for Brain Cancer, Asthma, and other 3 conditions demonstrating how our methodology effectively balances comprehensive coverage.

elements.filename: C:\Users\Shreya B\Documents\GitHub\slide-review-agent\data\logs\assets\amida vacm project presentation -may 2 2025 -final for mukundan\55_03.png

runs.text: Total number of unique ICD-10 Codes (ECE Output for 100 VASRD Codes): 44238 ICD-10 codes​
Total number of unique ICD-10 codes (ECE Output + Graph Theory for 100 VASRD Codes):

slides.title: Graph Theory: Results of ICD-10 Codes with Maximum of 13 VASRD Connections (92.5%ile)

runs.text: Graph Theory: Results of ICD-10 Codes with Maximum of 13 VASRD Connections (92.5%ile)

By applying the 92.5th percentile threshold, which means including the ICD-10 codes connected to a maximum of 13 VASRD codes, we produced 41,188 ICD-10 codes. This filtering threshold achieved balanced results across our test conditions: Sarcoidosis codes were narrowed down from Hannah's original set of 147 to 69 codes, while our ECE output reduced from 2,564 to 1,639 codes. Similar precision improvements are shown for Brain Cancer, Asthma, Fibromyalgia, Irritable Bowel Syndrome, and Breast Cancer in the table.

runs.text: Graph Theory: Results of ICD-10 Codes with Maximum of 16 VASRD Connections (85%ile)

threshold, which means by including the ICD-10 codes connected to a maximum of 10 VASRD codes resulted to 38,820 ICD-10 codes. This higher filtering threshold produced more focused results across our test conditions: Sarcoidosis codes were narrowed down from Hannah's original set of 147 to 53 codes, while our ECE output reduced from 2,564 to 1,320 codes. Similar precision improvements are shown for Brain Cancer, Asthma, Fibromyalgia, Irritable Bowel Syndrome and Breast Cancer in the table, demonstrating how adjusting the threshold can balance comprehensive coverage.

The flow begins with the selection of a medical condition, which initiates the ECE (Extraction, Compaction, Expansion) process. Next, a keyword confirmation step allows the user to review and validate the extracted terms for relevance and accuracy. Following this, an API call and post-filtering process refines the data to ensure only the most relevant medical codes are retained. The final step presents the results, displaying the VASRD mappings and medical codes, in a clear and actionable format.

runs.text: This image shows Step 1 of the VASRD Code(s) to Medical Code Mapping Tool. In this initial step, users are prompted to enter three key inputs of information: a 4-digit VASRD Code (with comma separation for multiple codes), the Disease/Condition Name ('Sarcoidosis' is shown as an example), and the Medical Code Type ('ICD-10' is selected) to generate keywords.

elements.filename: C:\Users\Shreya B\Documents\GitHub\slide-review-agent\data\logs\assets\amida vacm project presentation -may 2 2025 -final for mukundan\73_02.png

runs.text: This image shows Step 2 of the VASRD Code(s) to Medical Code Mapping Tool where the system generates and displays extracted and expanded keywords based on inputs from Step 1. In the "Extracted Keywords" section, a table presents relevant medical terms associated with the condition, automatically extracted from

descriptions and expanded using large language models based on the disease. The system has filtered these keywords to include only those relevant to the disease while removing duplicates and unnecessary terms, creating a focused set of medical terminology for mapping purposes.

elements.filename: C:\Users\Shreya B\Documents\GitHub\slide-review-agent\data\logs\assets\amida vacm project presentation -may 2 2025 -final for mukundan\74_02.png

runs.text: This image displays Step 3 of the VASRD code(s) to Medical Code Mapping Tool, showing the final mapping from VASRD Code to ICD-10 codes. The "Filtered Clinical Codes" section presents a table of ICD-10 codes that have been identified as relevant to the disease(Sarcoidosis, VASRD code 6846). In this final step, the keywords generated in Step 2 are sent to the UMLS API, which maps them to relevant medical codes. These API results are then processed through a language model for post-filtering, which retains only the codes specifically related to the disease based on code descriptions while removing unrelated results.
